Katherine Vaz was one of my favorite new to me authors last year, which earned her a â€œrecurring roleâ€ in my Deal Me In challenge for this year as the Ace of Hearts on my story roster. Iâ€™m slowly working my way through the tales in her collection â€œFado and Other Stories,â€ and this is the sixth one Iâ€™ve read. Last year, I posted about â€œUndressing the Vanity Dollsâ€ and â€œFado,â€ both of which I enjoyed immensely.

A cutesy way to summarize this story would be â€œKind of a Nikolai Gogol rewrites â€œThe Noseâ€ using an eyeball while assisted by Gabriel Garcia Marquez.â€ You see, Jose is in love with Ana. Ana is married but they have a secret place where they meet at regular intervals. Jose â€“ or â€œZeâ€ to his friends â€“ yearns for more and cherishes opportunities to see and observe her outside of their routine. One such opportunity presents itself in â€œThe Day of Contestsâ€ in the valley where they live. Though Ana is in attendance with her husband, Ze decides that distinguishing himself by accumulating the most points in all the contests will further insure Anaâ€™s devotion.

During the last of the contests he spots Ana in the crowd.

â€œA short, stocky man was resting his hand against the back of her neck, where the tips of her blonde hair lay, always, neatly. She was laughing at something he was saying. Was it the laughing done by married people who did not love each other but wanted to reassure others that any fighting would be done at homeâ€¦â€

Ze is an over-analzyer of everything in his affair with Ana. Every expression, every laugh, every look, every word. It is during the final contest that he has spotted Ana and her husband. During this contest, he also realizes heâ€™s over extended himself in his exertions in the prior ones, and he begins to slip into a sort of altered state of consciousness and then a prolonged hallucination or waking dream. In this dream, he is being punished by the people of the village in a sort of medieval â€œcucking chairâ€ (pictured below), being lowered into a river and held there. During this procedure his eyes pop out of their sockets(!) and though one is â€œeaten by a fishâ€ the other survives and takes us on a surreal journey through the town in search of his Ana.

I have to admit this story wasnâ€™t one that grabbed me right away, but the further I read the more fascinated I became with the new form of protagonist of the story. Its â€œobservationsâ€ weâ€™re unique and often quite humorous. I was reminded, too, how poetic Vazâ€™s writing is. At one point the eyeball is accidentally kicked by a passerby:

â€œThe kick left the eyeâ€™s vision blurred, and in the dimness it wonders if it were a boy again in the Azores, seeing the women in their doorways doing their embroidery in the last light of day â€“ Godâ€™s light â€“ because electricity was too expensive.â€

And once, when the eyeball is â€œpicked up cautiouslyâ€ by a dog:

â€œâ€¦in a mouth that was fragrant like rotting straw. The tongue was velvet, with those bumps that put everything eaten onto a pedestal of sorts before it is consumed.â€

Overall, an interesting read and one which has likely â€˜earnedâ€™ this author a spot in next yearâ€™s DMI roster as well. ğŸ™‚

Below: the author at an appearance at CUNY. The link below the picture also includes a brief video of her speaking about her writing, etc. Worth a watch â€“ itâ€™s only a few minutes long.

http://www.baruch.cuny.edu/wsas/academics/journalism/Vaz.htm

Itâ€™s week forty-six and I drew the seven of hearts. This is my second story from this author for this yearâ€™s Deal Me In short story reading challenge. I wrote about her â€œUndressing the The Vanity Dollsâ€ earlier this year, and it remains a strong contender for my favorite DMI story of 2014. I read, ad hoc, another story of hers this year titled, â€œThe Birth of Water Stories,â€ and was blown away by that one too. The story â€œFadoâ€ was not as moving as those other two (that, admittedly, set the bar quite high) but I continue to enjoy getting acquainted with this author.

Plus I learned a new word from this storyâ€™s title. ğŸ™‚ Do you know what a â€œFadoâ€ is? I do (now). Itâ€™s â€œa plaintive, Portuguese folk song.â€ Itâ€™s a perfect title for this â€œcover storyâ€ of the collection, and seems appropriate for the collection as a whole too. I also learned what a â€œwish ribbonâ€ was. One of the characters in this story puts great stock in their efficacy. Primarily, I believe, a Brazilian tradition, the wish ribbon enters this story when Xica is at the post office to pick up a ribbon â€œdo Nosso Senhor de Bonfimâ€ sent from that country by her cousin. How are they supposed to work? â€œWrap the wish ribbon around the wrist, and make 3 knots, making a wish for each of the 3 knots tied. Once the Brazilian Wish Bracelet falls off the wrist on its own, it is believed that the 3 wishes will come true.â€

In this story, â€œXicaâ€ is the neighbor and â€™surrogate grandmotherâ€™ of the young female narrator. Xica has endured many hardships and the worst of them is that her bright and promising son Manuel has been rendered mute and apparently brain damaged by an auto accident. Compounding the problem is that Manuelâ€™s young and beautiful wife, Marina, has lost interest in him because of the accident, where Xica feels she should be supporting him â€œin sickness and healthâ€ as the vows go.

Xica is one of the more interesting characters Iâ€™ve met during this yearâ€™s Deal Me In reading. I was particularly amused by the fact that she kept an â€œofensa ledgerâ€ wherein she catalogs the sins of those around her and proposes appropriate punishments. She knows that keeping such a register is Godâ€™s job but feels that â€œonce again, He was asleep.â€ Much of her grit, and unfortunately, her superstition and vengefulness as well are passed on to her surrogate granddaughter, Rosa.

The last few pages of the story feature an accelerated recap of Rosaâ€™s growing into a woman after Xica has passed on. I believe it is in these chapters that we see how Rosa has applied what she learned from Xicaâ€™s somewhat unique approach to life. We see her through her fist sexual encounter â€œSex happens the way a pearl is formed. It begins with a grain or parasitic worm that itches in the soft lining until the entire animal buckles around it. With enough slathering it will relax into a gem.â€ Not bad, huh?

Rosa even later makes peace with Marina and tends to her when she becomes sick, leaving us with our other â€œtake awayâ€ from the story: Rosa tells us, â€œHere is the seal from which all grace comes: We must create Pietas in order to live. Flesh that is torn, flesh that is dead or dying, even as it is rotting through your fingers â€“ hold it next to your heart. Find ripe and tender flesh too, and hold it in your arms, because your life depends on it. Hold it for as long as you can, and ask for its blessing.â€

Below: Michelangeloâ€™s â€œPietaâ€

Okay, so after reviewing the story in accompaniment of writing this post, Iâ€™ve decided that I like this story almost as much as the other anyway. ğŸ™‚ There is some powerful stuff in these thirteen pages.

Have you read Kahteirne Vaz before? I can unreservedly recommend her.

Only six stories left to read for DMI 2014!

This week for my Deal Me In Short Story Reading Challenge I drew the â€œmustache-lessâ€ King of Hearts (heâ€™s the only king without a mustache â€“ a fun bit of trivia I only learned today when preparing this post).

Did you also know that the four kings in the standard deck of cards also supposedly represent four historical kings? The King of Hearts is Charlemagne, while Spades = King David, Clubs = Alexander the Great, and Diamonds, depending on who you ask = Julius or Augustus Caesar. Okay, done with the trivia. ğŸ™‚

For this yearâ€™s challenge, Hearts are my suit for stories recommended by others. (Update 4/12/14: actually I have this wrong: diamonds are my â€œrecommended by othersâ€ suit. I had more stories recommended by others that I had room for in that suit and a few bled into other suits. Hearts is actually my suit for women authors) Katherine Vaz is a Portugese-American writer who I learned about in quite a random way. Often, after our monthly meetings at the Kurt Vonnegut Library book club, some of us will adjourn to a nearby restaurant (named after the Vonnegut novel, Bluebeard) for lunch. Last July, it was just going to be two of us going, so I agreed with my colleague to â€œjust meet you over there.â€ I got there first, and when he arrived he had two strangers with him. Seems he had been chatting with some â€œinternational visitorsâ€ in the library and, when asked to recommend a good place for lunch, did what any fine ambassador of our city would do and invited them along. They were in town for a â€œPortuguese Diasporaâ€ conference (apparently thereâ€™s one every year somewhere in the world) at Butler University. We enjoyed a nice lunch and also a sharing of our literary interests. Long story short, I saw this as excellent opportunity to collect some reading recommendations. I explained my annual short story reading challenge to our guests, and they offered several Portuguese authors to consider. One was Katherine Vaz, and Iâ€™ve included two of her stories from her collection â€œFado and Other Storiesâ€ in my 2014 roster.

I got off to a slow start with this story and was worried I wouldnâ€™t like it. I even remember thinking, well, at least I learned what vanity dolls are (â€œpeople use them to displace vain desires. If a nun, or any devout person, painted a ball-gown onto a doll and gave it new earrings, the doll absorbed her wish to have those things. A doll dressed as a sailor could cure a travel bug, and one painted with flowers could relieve one of carnal aches.â€) Iâ€™d never heard of vanity dolls before, and I guess Iâ€™ve assumed they really exist and arenâ€™t just a vehicle for this story. Does anyone know?

Anyway, the story really blossomed the more of it I read. The main character, Reginald, now an astronomer, is making a visit to an old favorite botany professor of his (from twenty years ago) who is dying. The hook of the story is that Reginald has always suspected that there was once â€œsomething betweenâ€ the professor (Eduardo Dias) and Reginaldâ€™s wife, Alicia. Reginald has never directly confronted Alicia with his suspicions, but has hinted around the bush about it for years. Appropriately, Vaz describes his marriage thus: â€œReginaldâ€™s marriage to Alicia was redolent with what was withheld, which made it an ordinary, garden-variety union.â€

Dias was/is an inveterate charmer, and Reginald has before told his wife that Dias â€œâ€¦had that ability to make everyone feel that he, or she, I suppose, was the only other person alive. Itâ€™s a gift. He was like that with me.â€ On Reginaldâ€™s visit to the dying man, Dias insists he take him to the seashore, as a red tide will be coming in, and he wants to see it. Reginald is spellbound by the phenomenon and thinks of Dias that â€œâ€¦he still knew the best secrets. He had a way of making you want to give him something in return.â€ His visit to Dias also leads him to know, â€œbetter than he has ever knownâ€¦ that vitality is plainly the cloak that sexuality wears, so that it can go out in public. That was what his professor was made of, that was his cloak, his finery.â€

Vazâ€™s writing in the final pages of this story totally wowed me. An example: â€œThe red tide was drifting south, the neon blue receding, and as easily as that, as easily and swiftly as a comet arrives, passes on, and does not return again, not in oneâ€™s lifetime, the moment for Dias to ask Reginald why he had given him the silent treatment, and for Reginald to ask if the letters were never for Alicia out of a well-founded guilt, came and left, and would present its chance to be regarded no more. Such nullifying moments exist, and their vacancy is as strong as all else that one might name.â€

That passage â€“ especially the last sentence â€“ gave me goosebumps, and did again just now as I typed this. So â€¦ I guess I liked this story. ğŸ™‚

What about you? Have you heard of or read this author? What about other Portuguese or Portuguese-American writers? Id love to hear of them.
